text: Good morning.
Nice to see you all.
And it's good to be back.

I was just reflecting that it's
been 10 years since we first
started convening here.

And I just wanted to
see a show of hands,

is there anyone else, other
than Robin, Lakshmi, and myself

and a couple of
other people I know,

who has actually been here and
been coming to all of them?
I know Tina's been here as well.
So isn't that really exciting?

It's kind of surreal to know
that we've been convening.

Love the embrace
of the philosophy

of this symposium
and the name change,

so congratulations
in getting that done.

So like Tina and Beth, I
come at my research work

through a very grounded-- from
a very grounded perspective.

And the grounded
perspective that I'm

going to share insights
with you today from

is how I came to think
about power, anxiety,

sociocultural ideals,
and my leaping framework

through my teaching with my
students at the Wharton School.

So when I arrived at
Wharton in 2017 as--

that was my second
position as junior faculty,

I was invited to teach a
class on diversity, equity,
and inclusion.

And I had no idea
what that meant

or what that experience
was going to be like,

particularly coming on the
heels of the 2016 Presidential

Election at, again, the
Wharton School where

I was teaching this class on
diversity, equity, inclusion.

So, I actually thought
that my students

who were taking my
elective classes--

I have undergraduate
and MBA classes,

I thought they
were going to look
like the people in this room.

But instead, I found
myself educating

a lot of people who
identify as being more
from majority groups.

And so as I was sharing all
of our wonderful insights

and research with
this group, they

would make a line
outside my office

to have one-on-one appointments
to begin to share with me what

I have now characterized as
varying degrees of anxiety
about this topic.

So my research agenda
shifted naturally

to really try to
figure out, how can I

be helpful to
people who feel very
anxious about these topics?

And how can I begin to
understand that as a catalyst?

That said, today I will
ground some of this work

and focus on
cross-racial allyship,

though my frameworks spans
multiple marginalized groups,

including gender and the
intersections in-between.

And certainly, I
talk about things,

lots of emotions-- this
one will focus on anxiety,
but I did my homework, Robin.

I also tried to link it to
the theme of the conference,

and I choose to
embrace love today.
So, let's talk about love.

Many of you know, this
is like really cliche,
especially as I'm standing here.
Many of you know that--

I guess-- I don't know if
it's newly or recently engaged

and I'm getting
married in October.
Thank you.

And so I'm thinking
a lot about love.

So much so that when Robin

to ponder, this one
really stood out to me,

and I'd like to
channel this in us

for us as I talk about
allyship in a bit.

And so this is actually an

book, Love and Rage--

The Path of Liberation
through Anger--

Lama will be here
tomorrow, so I'm just
previewing some of this work.

"Love isn't actually
meant to feel good,

nor is it meant to
be fun all the time.

Real love and true love
actually can bring us

into complex,
challenging situations,

and that is the thing about love
which people don't understand.

When you understand
that about love,

we can enter into a more
authentic, direct, and honest

relationship with ourselves
and how we relate to others.
So this verb love--

this verb love-- is this act
and wish to experience freedom.

Being free sometimes,
though, is not so easy."

So as we think about
allyship, with me, at least,

today, I want you to think about
allyship as love, as an act.

Not just an experience,
but as an act of love,

as potentially an act
of love, and what would

it look like if we were
to re-envision allyship
in that way.
So what is allyship?
Why is it important?

How do we think about being
an ally to Racial Minority
Professionals?

Which I we'll abbreviate as our
RMPs for the sake of brevity.

What we know from research
is that across a variety

of domains, many of
you know who also

studied this topic,
allyship, you know,
that it crosses disciplines.

But collectively, if you
think about this, what we know

is that allyship is often
defined as something that

occurs when an individual
with some degree of power

or privilege provides
some type of support

to someone from a marginalized
group who has relatively

less power or privilege,
and the idea behind this

is we're trying to reduce
some type of disparity,
just to keep it broad for now.

We know that allyship
has the potential

to promote the well-being of
racial minority professionals.

That it's important for helping
to advance racial minority

professionals to
leadership roles.

But one thing that
we often forget--

and I'd like to continue
to bring front and center,

is that people who are from both
minority and minority groups

have the potential to be
allies to racial minority
professionals.

So I as a Black woman
have the potential to be

an ally to other Black
women, Black men, et cetera.

So as I've been trying to help
my students understand what

they can do and should do
and try to be, I think,

prescriptive but
also evidence-based,

is as I begin to disentangle
across a wide variety

of literatures, when we talk
about allyship actions, what

are these things, how might we
categorize and conceptualize
them?

In a conceptual paper, I've
talked about LEAP allyship

behavior broadly, but
I've also had the chance

to collect stories from hundreds
of people about allyship

broadly, but also about
cross-racial allyship broadly,

and it largely coalesces
around these four
categories of allyship actions.
There's a big L in here--

Looking, Listening,
Learning, and Locating

oneself, Engaging in
discussions, A deeper dive

into the interaction, which
is asking probing questions,
and Providing support.
I want to-- where is Rae?
Rae.

One of the initial
versions of this paper,

and one day I will get back
to it, is very somatic.

But I think as a
field, we are still

working through
embracing emotions
as part of the things we study.

I do believe we have a long
way to go before we can all

collectively understand
how to integrate
somatic concepts into our work.

So help me out as I begin
to think later about--

to better articulate the
somatic version of this paper.
OK.

So I'm going to start from
a place of top-down allyship

initiatives, and
what I mean by this

is basically formal
diversity interventions
that organizations implement.

And many of you who've
been part of these.

I've been part of these
where organizations say,

hey, we want to mandate
allyship training

or we want to create
an intervention whereby

all of our managers
or employees are

going to learn
from you, academic,
about how to be an ally.

So that's what I mean by a
top-down allyship initiative as

opposed to, you're just
trying to be a good person

and work with somebody
else through the things
that they need.

So these the catalysts for these
top-down allyship initiatives
are often social justice crises.

Again, they're
organization-sponsored

campaigns, programs,
and trainings.

They tend to focus on centering
a visible and vocal support

of professionals
from historically
marginalized groups at work.

And these campaigns
can prescribe

a range of allyship
actions ranging

from listening to people
share their stories about bias

and mistreatment, all
the way to advocacy.

However, what I
submit in my work

is that this formal dynamic
can evoke managerial anxiety

if we focus on managers
as often the targets

of these initiatives--
people managers, if you will.

And so these top-down
allyship initiative,

they're a type of
diversity intervention,
let's not forget that.

And what diversity
interventions are all about
is about organizational change.

So as we start to track
that, what we then see is,

well, naturally, we
know from our research

that change initiatives
often do and can

evoke managerial anxiety because
they make organizational power
dynamics salient.

And so if you look
at the graphic here,

this is what I'm talking
about, is as from a managerial

perspective, this top-down
diversity intervention,

allyship initiative, feels very
much as if it's implemented
by someone--

someones, senior leaders--
who control the social order.

And that anxiety
is a manifestation

of my experience of feeling
like this is being done to me,
not done with me or done for me.

I'm not going to go
through the whole model,

but this is where
I'm going with this.

Is, as we think about power
dynamics and managerial anxiety

as catalysts-- in this
paper, I actually talk

about many versions of
allyship, but just let's

focus on cross-racial for
now for the sake of today.

We're talking about these
top-down workplace allyship

initiatives catalyzing
this managerial anxiety

and that leading to
LEAP allyship behavior.

I'm going to complicate this
for us in just a moment,

but that's where
I'm going with this.

But what is I think
important to recognize is,

from a lay perspective, but also
from an academic perspective,

we don't all have the
same understanding of what
allyship behavior actually is.

In fact, if you read the
critical and feminist

perspective on
allyship behavior,

you will read a
lot about allyship

as structurally
oriented and necessarily

incorporating
considerations of power
and having outcomes for power.

And so the actions
that are often

described in this
literature are aimed

at challenging or changing
inequitable systems
and structures.

And so those are the assumptions
implicit and explicit

about what allyship
is in this literature.

Now I'm going to make this
sound like dichotomous,
but there's a fuzzy set here.

So if we go to the other side,
if we were to create clarity

around another scholarly way
of thinking about allyship,

we can turn to what I'm just
broadly characterizing as more
psychological perspective.

Again, I acknowledge
there's some overlap here.

But if you look at this
body of literature,

how it talks about
allyship is pretty

much as an individualized
set of remedies.

Actions aimed at engaging in
self-reflection-- so as Tina

was talking about
digging, how much we dig

varies widely in
this literature.

Acknowledging that
there are different

experiences that
we have as members

of advantaged, disadvantaged,
and intersectional-advantaged
and disadvantaged groups.

The importance of
becoming knowledgeable

about different social identity
groups and their experiences,

addressing bias, affirming

But really, fundamentally
focused on the interpersonal

one-on-one individually
"let me help you"

as opposed to change
the system dynamic.

So I found this
quite interesting.

And so have the people
who have read my work.

And so one of the
things that we started

to think about is
what would it look

like as opposed to deciding

And what is allyship and
what is not allyship?

What would happen if we

as arrayed along a spectrum?

And this spectrum being
one in which there

are more conservative--
i.e., restricted forms

of leap allyship
behavior, all the way

to these more progressive

forms of allyship.

So this is the place
where I sit and this

is the place from where
I theorize and conduct

my research is imagining
that there is a range.

That said, I think

And so as we think about

here's how I would like you

So you'll see that the

And so if we're thinking about

this self-reflective space,

what can come out of
this process of inquiry,

of self-reflection for someone

is the sentiment that they

And a lack of acknowledgment
around other external factors,

including people, who might
have supported their capacity
to be there.

The E, the Engaging
in discussions

for a restricted LEAPer might

in this case, it could

"It's sad that
women are struggling

to get here in
this organization--
in our organization."

And making an assumption that

that you've managed to

So it's kind of like, OK, I

or it's that you didn't seem

have struggled, too,
just like other people.

The A is Asking probing
questions as opposed

to asking deep,
thoughtful questions.

It becomes really
focused on asking

marginalized professionals
about what have they done?
Have they asked?
Have they leaned in?

Have they told their manager
that they wanted to lead?

So the onus of
responsibility, there's

an assumption, either

that it is-- that
the circumstances

that the historically

is based on their
lack of effort,

just as if they consider
their own effort as predicting
their own experiences.

And the P, Providing
support for this person,

might be something that
also similarly suggests

individualized efforts should
be the catalyst for change.

Wear pants if you want
to be taken seriously.
Learn to play golf.
This is for you, Tina.

Straighten your hair if you want
to be viewed as a professional.

And put your head
down and work harder.

So I'm not suggesting
that this is not allyship.

I'm calling it a
restricted LEAP behavior,
a restricted form of allyship.

It can be helpful, some people
might feel helped by this,

but it is something that is much
more restricted than others.

And so what is the
potential outcome

of restricted LEAP behavior
and with respect to the power
dynamics?
This reinforces the status quo.

So responsive LEAP behavior, now
we're moving toward the middle.

With respect to
responsive behavior,

as we begin to walk
through this paradigm here,

we see a little bit
more deeper exploration
of the self of one's experience.

It's the acknowledgment that

In engaging with someone who

imagining saying

Given all that you've

there's some sense of

The questions that
they ask are more

The willingness to

And then with respect
to providing support,

it might look something more
like, how can I introduce you

to the opportunities
in the resources
that I've had access to?

And so I suggest
that this actually

might destabilize the power
imbalance because by sharing

resources, by sharing
opportunities,

we begin to challenge the
notion that I can do it myself
and I should do it myself.

And then that would
take us lastly

to the final group,
which I would suggest

is the most progressive
form of allyship, I think,

is the closest to Tina and
Beth's Shared Sisterhood model
here.

And so as we think
about this reflexivity,

this self-reflection for people

we've stood by and
have not spoken up

when we've observed other

people's experiences.

Communicating that
you want to make

sure that your experiences,
perspectives, and ideas

yours as a potential ally.

So now we're moving
into this more
of this co-conspirator mindset.

Asking questions that are

And then if you are

in a place where the other

your co-conspirator,
is not present,

acknowledging them as a
contributor to the ideas

that you are sharing
as to what needs
to be done in the organization.

So for example, saying to

a group of our Black
colleagues and I

met and we think it's time

and promotion practices.

So the idea here is giving

And so I suggest that this
might change power structures

because it subverts
the status quo.

All right, so quickly,
the emotion that I

use to explain how we have
these different variations

in restricted response of
elite behavior is anxiety,

and I recognize that there's
not one form of anxiety,
there are at least three.

And the anxiety that
we often talk about

is actually the preventive
kind, this self-focused, nearly

paralytic, but not quite,
inhibitory form of anxiety.

And that's what I
would suggest often

leads people to engage in
these more restricted forms
of allyship.

Now that is different from the
other end, promotive anxiety,

which is a much more, I would
call it, achiever's anxiety.

A future-oriented state of,
I am anxious that we will not

be able to create
a more equitable,

inclusive organization
and society

if we don't get this right, and
that's the anxiety that I feel.

And the one in the
middle is the one

in the middle, the
mix of the two.

This is a paper where I
suggest that while I've

been talking about
top-down allyship

initiatives as something
that organizations create,

the reality is that in many
of our organizations today,

nobody's telling
anybody what to do,

and so there's a lot of
bumbling around as people

try to figure out
what does it mean
to be an ally in this context.

And so one of the context that
I've studied where this happens

is the US Army, where there
isn't a lot of prescriptive
around what people should do.

And so I look at the
experiences and the actions

of male managers who
are Black and white men,
male senior officers.

And so what I suggest in
this paper is that as opposed

to having a directive from
the top in terms of what they

should do, they tend to lean on
the implicit norms and beliefs

and ideals that are
baked into the system

as a way of determining
what they should engage in.

And so I talk about
these as white
hegemonic masculine ideals.

I'm going to place
a bookmark here

because Sanaz is going to
say a whole lot about that.
He's like perfect, right?

So Sanaz will say
more about that.

But this idea that these
are the cultural ideals,

the gendered and
racialized cultural ideals
that underlie the Army culture.

And what happens
for male managers

is that they implicitly
and unconsciously absorb

these beliefs and they begin
to explain their career
trajectories through this lens.

And so for the group of
allies who I call providers,

they believe that they got
there through meritocracy

and colorblindness, protectors
believe they got there

through conforming
and outperforming,

and promoters believe that they
got there through networking
and visibility.

And if you just scroll
all the way to the right,

basically what I'm suggesting
is the form of support

that they then give to
racial minority professionals

reflects these internalized
beliefs around what

type of help you should need
based on the type of help
I think I got.

At the end of the day, the
punchline for this story,

and I think what tends
to trigger people

about this paper, is I
say, that's all great,

but the reality is, we have
the unintended consequences

of reifying the very system
that necessitated allyship
in the first place.

The last thing I will
say here before I end

is that I come in and out of
should we organize and teach

people how to do the
things or should we

let them figure
it out themselves?

I have a paper that
has three studies,

and it's a quantitative paper
where I was, like many of you,

invited by a company to
do race-focused diversity

training in the months
following George Floyd's murder.

And so all of these other
papers were floating around,

and what I really
wanted to understand

was, what are the conditions
under which I could help them

to make this diversity
training that they want me
to do as effective as possible?

It was mandated, it was all
the things-- it was managers,

it felt like it could be
potentially very tense,
and it was.

But what we ended
up finding out was,

the quality of the
interactions that people

had with their relational
partners during the training

really was the deciding
factor as to whether or not

they engaged in post-training
allyship behavior.

So this is to say that
diversity training,

educational experiences,
obviously they're

not the end all, be all, but to
the extent that we can create

experiences where people
begin to feel that I feel

known and understood and
validated for who I am,

even if they're talking
about my identity

as really as a husband and a
father and not a white person,

we let that sit
and we appreciate

that as being
someone's experience,

particularly if
we're trying to think

about how to get someone
who sees themselves

only through that lens to
engage in allyship behavior
after the training.

So songs pop in my head a
lot when I'm doing research,

and as I was reflecting
on this and love,

I started thinking
about this song,

because what always feels
missing for me in my allyship

research is the
experience of people who
were trying to support in this.

And I certainly
have other research

that's focused on
how we as people

who are from
historically-marginalized

groups process the world and
try to accumulate support
and resources for ourselves.

And so for me, as I
think about allyship,

would also becomes important
is to understand that for many

of us who want an ally,
it's about wanting

you to show us that
you love us in the way
that we want to be loved.

And that therein lies the

is, how do we get there?

So I don't have any answers for
